By James Clay

Nouse sits down with nightclub photographer and University of York student Felix Wahlberg.

YUSU celebrates and recognises the voluntary work of students across York

By James Clay

Student volunteers acknowledged during Student Volunteering Week 2023

Local Plan for York under consideration

By James Clay

Plans for future investment in housing and infrastructure are being debated by the local council

UCU strikes stood down

By Gracie Daw

Action on 21, 22, 23, 27, 28 February and 1 and 2 March will not go ahead

YUSU Election Results 2023

By James Clay

Pierrick Roger re-elected as YUSU President

YUSU Election Results 2023

By James Clay

Pierrick Roger re-elected as YUSU President

York falls in Sunday Times league table

The University of York has fallen two places in the <em>Sunday Times</em> University league table, now ranking at 15th place (Thumbnail credit Credit: Philippa Grafton)

First 'Live and Loud' acts announced

YUSU have announced the first two acts for this year's Freshers Ball as DJ Fresh and Rizzle Kicks.

YUSU severs ties with Fibbers

Fibbers has been dropped as an official YUSU affiliated nighclub, it was announced today (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Justyn Hardcastle)

Government to shake up allocation of undergraduate places

The University may be forced to compete for over half of its undergraduate intake from 2012 under government plans. (Thumbnail credit The goverment plans to lift the cap on University places for any student with A-Level results of AAB+. Image credit: Julien)

Sunday Times Editor receives Honorary degree amidst allegations

The awarding of an Honorary Degree to the<em> Sunday Times</em> Editor, John Witherow, is to go ahead despite accusations by Gordon Brown surrounding the way personal information was gathered by the newspaper (Thumbnail credit As editor of the Sunday Times, Witherow has been implicated in the ongoing press misconduct scandal. Image: The Guardian)

Lack of campus security leads to further burglaries

The University has been hit by two burglaries in the space of four days with Halifax College and the corner room in Langwith being targeted by thieves gaining access through poorly secured windows (Thumbnail credit Electronic equipment was stolen through poorly secured windows in both Halifax and Langwith rooms. Image credit: Andy Polaine)

Woodstock 2011 raises over PS8,000 for RAG

The total amount that Woodstock raised for RAG this year has been announced as PS8,263.14

Bar staff assaulted during Halifax football social

Members of the Halifax firsts football team have been criticised for anti-social behaviour on Thursday night, after allegedly throwing eggs and stones at bar staff members, having been refused service in D-bar

York falls in Times University table

York has fallen two places in the Times Good University guide, dropping out of the top ten. The survey, released this week, ranked the University of York eleventh in the country

YUSU confirm PS2.2 million Student Centre expansion

The YUSU Student Centre in James College will undergo an estimated PS2.2million expansion over the summer holiday period (Thumbnail credit The proposed design from the front of the Student Centre. Credit: YUSU)

University of York to charge PS9,000 tuition fees

The University of York will charge PS9,000 per year in Undergraduate tuition fees for students from October 2012 (Thumbnail credit Credit: George Lowther)

Sabbatical Review: successes and failures of the outgoing team

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em> analyses how this year's Sabbatical Officers have fared in what many have termed a turbulent year for students

Rugby club slammed for racism

By James Bithell

Individuals in the University of York rugby club look to face severe disciplinary action after posting several highly racist comments on the clubs' official Twitter account last Thursday (Thumbnail credit Individuals in UYRUFC have been condemned by students for posting offensive racial slurs on the club Twitter account. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

ISA to help internationalise campus

The International Students' Association (ISA) will be launching its Global Initiative Fund this week to provide support to students or societies who would like "to embark on a project that would internationalise the campus"

Catering hub will not be ready for Langwith in 2012 says University

The University has come under pressure from YUSU and College Chairs to confirm when the planned Social and Catering Building for Heslington East will be built (Thumbnail credit The Ron Cooke Hub is currently the only catering service on Heslington East but offers limited services. Photo: BDP)

Health Centre failing its trans patients

Concerns have been raised surrounding the Campus Health Centre's treatment of trans students after requests for incorrect patient details on medical records to be changed have been denied (Thumbnail credit Health Centres across the country abide by the NHS agreement which says details should be changed in 21 days. Photo: SMUC)

Welfare software to cost PS20,000

The University is set to spend PS20,000 on an interactive mental health training programme for staff and students

YUSU protest divides college support

A peaceful protest highlighting the need for a social and catering facility on the Heslington East campus has erupted in controversy (Thumbnail credit A picnic protest against the University is planned to take place today in the Ron Cooke Hub on Heslington East. Photo: Robbophotos)

Departments miss feedback deadline

Several departments have failed to meet University deadlines for returning feedback. The Environment Department has taken nearly 13 weeks to provide students with feedback. The delay has left many students uncertain about how to revise and improve their work in the future

Campus bridge deteriorating

Potential dangers found in the structure of Vanbrugh Bridge have led the University to begin proceedings to have it replaced in its entirety (Thumbnail credit Vanbrugh bridge is due to be replaced by the end of this year after it was found to be structurally unsound. Photo: Peter Iveson)

Supervisor standards are a "departmental lottery"

Early results from the Student Experience Survey indicated that over 20 per cent of the students in their departments across York had a unsatisfying experience with the supervisory system within their department (Thumbnail credit Students have voiced concerns about the level of supervision on courses. Photo: University of York)

Late night license events under threat

The financial viability of late night college events has been questioned by Commercial Services, but it has been met by strong denial from College JCRCs

Fairfax House petition for compensation

Students in Fairfax House, Vanbrugh College, are petitioning the University for a partial refund as a result of the substandard accommodation they believe they have received (Thumbnail credit Students in Fairfax claim they have been overcharged for their rooms. Photo: Peter Iveson)

How green is York?

Martin Spurr looks at how sustainable the University is and what improvements are being undertaken

YUSU shortlisted for NUS Award

It has been announced that YUSU have been shortlisted in the 2011 NUS Awards, for the Endsleigh Technology Innovation Award (Thumbnail credit Credit: NUS)

Karin Diaconu elected GSA President

Karin Diaconu has been elected as the new President of the Graduate Student Association (Thumbnail credit Credit: GSA)

York continues to drop in 'Green League' rankings

The University of York has been ranked 83rd in the 2011 People and Planet Green League out of 142 universities for its environment and ethics performance. (Thumbnail credit Credit: People and Planet)

Inquest rules drugs as cause of student death

An inquest into the death of a University of York student this week has concluded that he died because of a dependency on drugs (Thumbnail credit James Matthews )

York graduate prospects plummet

With national graduate employment research indicating a 33 per cent increase in graduate job applications this year, it is feared this will have a detrimental affect on the already poor graduate employment statistics at York (Thumbnail credit The careers service faces criticsism as York graduates struggle for jobs)

Students start up ethical campus shop

A group of students have started up Scoop, a food cooperative on campus, selling a variety of grocery items such as locally sourced organic vegetable boxes

The University of York has fallen two places in the <em>Sunday Times</em> University league table, now ranking at 15th place (Thumbnail credit Credit: Philippa Grafton)
